title: CONFIG-DRIVEN FRONTEND FRAMEWORK
description: Designed, built, and owned an internal config-driven UI platform at Frugal Scientific, built on React (Vite), Material UI, Redux Toolkit, and Redux-Saga. The system enables teams to generate complete enterprise admin interfaces—tables, forms, filters, drawers, permissions, and CRUD workflows—entirely from declarative configuration. Built for high reuse, controlled extensibility, and long-term maintainability, it is now the company-wide standard powering multiple production products.
problem_statement: Across logistics and master-data products, admin interfaces followed nearly identical patterns but were implemented repeatedly with custom React components and Redux logic. This resulted in large-scale code duplication, inconsistent UX behavior, slow feature delivery, and high maintenance cost when requirements changed.
design_decisions: Adopted a declarative, config-first approach to define admin modules instead of duplicating React code
Built a single orchestrator component that renders tables, drawers, and forms dynamically from menu configuration
Standardized async behavior using Redux-Saga to centrally handle API orchestration, filters, sorting, and pagination
Implemented a multi-keyed Redux state architecture to isolate data, loading state, and caching per admin module
Designed a flexible field-rendering system supporting complex data types, nested objects, and custom render overrides
Introduced controlled escape hatches via a Form Registry, allowing injection of custom React forms when configuration alone is insufficient
impact_metrics: Adopted as the standard admin UI platform across 5+ production projects
Used daily by co-developers across multiple teams
Powers 100+ admin screens generated primarily from configuration
Reduced time to build a new admin menu section from 2–3 days to 1–2 hours
Reduced frontend codebase size by ~50% by eliminating duplicated admin logic
Eliminated the equivalent of hundreds of thousands of lines of redundant UI code across products
technical_highlights: Built with React + Vite for fast builds and modern development workflow
Material UI used as the base design system with framework-level consistency
Redux-Saga used for complex async flows including dynamic filter query construction
Supports role-based permissions, base filters, default sorting, and API module routing via configuration
Configuration supports nested object mapping, constant value injection, computed fields, and custom cell renderers
Custom React form components can be injected per module when advanced validation or workflows are required

title: ODR Session Platform — Turn-Based Video Session Orchestration
role: Product Engineer — Real-Time Orchestration & Access Control
description: Designed and implemented a session orchestration layer to solve turn-based access control for online arbitration and mediation workflows within an existing ODR platform. Based on a product-level direction defined by the CTO to avoid building a custom video conferencing system, I designed a real-time orchestration solution that integrates with existing tools like Google Meet and Zoom. The system manages participant sequencing, access control, and session lifecycle through a FIFO waiting lobby, controlled meeting-link reveal, and automated notifications, enabling structured virtual proceedings without additional video infrastructure.
problem_statement: In the existing ODR platform, arbitrators and mediators were manually sharing public video conference links, making it difficult to enforce turn-based participation, prevent early entry, and manage large scheduled sessions. While building a custom video system could address this, it would significantly increase complexity and maintenance cost.
design_decisions: Designed a FIFO-based waiting lobby to manage fair, turn-based participant sequencing
Implemented controlled reveal of existing video meeting links instead of building a custom video layer
Used WebSockets (Socket.IO) to synchronize lobby state, queue position, and chat in real time
Implemented OTP-based authentication with unique invite tokens for low-friction public access
Handled disconnect and rejoin scenarios while preserving queue position and session state
Automated invitations, reminders, and session lifecycle transitions using cron-based background jobs
impact_metrics: Supported 50+ participants per session with real-time queue visibility and orderly turn management
Enabled multiple concurrent arbitration and mediation sessions
Significantly reduced manual coordination and moderation effort for arbitrators
Delivered a focused, low-maintenance orchestration layer without custom video infrastructure

title: DIATADMIN — CLIENT-FACING ADMINISTRATIVE SYSTEM
description: Delivered a custom administrative system for DIAT, a multi-branch technical institute, by working directly with non-technical stakeholders to translate academic, financial, and operational workflows into a maintainable full-stack solution. Owned backend APIs, data modeling, authentication, and VPS deployment alongside the frontend, focusing on clarity, reliability, and cost-aware engineering rather than infrastructure scale while delivering the system from requirements through production. Implemented a QR-based student identity feature that allows secure public access to student profiles, academic records, and fee payment statements via scanned IDs.
problem_statement: DIAT relied on spreadsheets and disconnected tools to manage admissions, academics, finances, and inventory across branches, leading to inconsistent data, duplicated effort, and limited operational visibility.
design_decisions: Identified branch isolation as a core business requirement and implemented branch-scoped data access and permissions within a single shared deployment
Translated informal administrative workflows into explicit system rules for admissions, attendance, fee handling, expenses, and inventory movement
Structured backend modules around real organizational domains (Academic, Finance, Inventory) to align the system with departmental responsibilities
Centralized authentication and role-based access control to simplify user management across branches
Designed a QR-based student identity mechanism to enable controlled public access to student academic and financial information without requiring full authentication
Recognized financial data loss as a critical operational risk and implemented a lightweight, zero-cost automated backup flow using existing cloud storage
Chose a simple VPS-based deployment model to minimize operational overhead and ensure the system could be maintained without dedicated infrastructure staff
impact_metrics: Used daily by administrators across 4 active branches
Replaced fragmented manual and spreadsheet-driven workflows with a unified system
Enabled QR-based student identity verification for quick access to academic and fee information
Improved reliability and auditability of academic and financial operations
Delivered a maintainable solution aligned with tight budget and operational constraints

title: FINTECH FIELD OPERATIONS & REPORTING DASHBOARD — PRODUCT OWNERSHIP
role: Frontend Product Engineering — Analytics & Geo Systems
description: Owned and delivered the complete frontend system of a fintech field-operations and reporting platform for a loan recovery company, working closely with a senior backend engineer. Took responsibility for frontend system design, data flow modeling, and UI/UX decisions based on backend API contracts. Implemented field-agent tracking using API polling, where mobile devices periodically send geo-location updates to the server and the frontend reconstructs time-ordered movement paths and visit timelines from coordinate arrays. Built hierarchy-based dashboards used by regional heads, state heads, managers, and operations teams to monitor collections, attendance, visits, and performance. Integrated Frappe APIs, Google Maps, and OpenStreetMap to support geospatial visualization and operational reporting.
problem_statement: Loan recovery operations lacked centralized visibility into field-agent activity and hierarchical performance metrics. Existing systems were fragmented, relied heavily on manual reporting, and did not provide timely operational insights for decision-makers.
design_decisions: Owned frontend system architecture and UI/UX decisions while integrating with backend APIs developed by a senior backend engineer
Implemented polling-based geo-location visualization to ensure reliable tracking across varying mobile network conditions
Reconstructed agent movement paths and visit timelines from ordered geo-coordinate arrays on the frontend
Designed hierarchy-driven reporting views aggregating data across regional head, state head, manager, and field-officer levels
Integrated Google Maps and OpenStreetMap for route visualization, nearby-party discovery, and operational context
Built frontend workflows for CRUD operations, task assignments, and activity logs to support daily field operations
impact_metrics: Enabled centralized visibility into real-time and historical field-agent movement through frontend-driven visualization
Improved decision-making for managers through hierarchy-based reporting dashboards
Reduced dependency on manual status tracking and ad-hoc reports
Supported daily monitoring and coordination of large field teams in loan recovery operations

title: PRODUCTION ADMIN PLATFORM REFACTOR — FRONTEND SCALABILITY
description: Led the refactoring of a large production admin platform at Frugal Scientific, reducing the frontend codebase from approximately 100K to 50K lines of code. Took ownership of restructuring component boundaries, eliminating duplicated logic, and standardizing state and data-handling patterns to improve maintainability, readability, and long-term scalability without feature loss.
problem_statement: The existing admin platform had grown organically with duplicated components, tightly coupled logic, and inconsistent patterns, making feature development slow, error-prone, and difficult to scale as product requirements evolved.
design_decisions: Identified and eliminated duplicated UI and state-management logic across multiple admin modules
Refactored large, tightly coupled components into smaller, reusable, and composable units
Standardized data-fetching, loading states, and error handling across the application
Improved separation of concerns between UI rendering, business logic, and API integration layers
Aligned the refactored structure with long-term scalability and future extensibility goals
impact_metrics: Reduced frontend codebase size by ~50% without feature loss
Improved developer productivity and onboarding by simplifying code structure
Reduced maintenance overhead and risk of regression during feature changes
Prepared the platform for future feature expansion with a cleaner and more scalable foundation

title: LOGISTICS CRM UI/UX RESTRUCTURING — ROLE-BASED DASHBOARDS
description: Co-led a UI/UX restructuring of a large logistics CRM platform in close collaboration with the UX design team. Took ownership of frontend implementation and information-architecture decisions, transforming the system from a menu-heavy, module-scattered interface into a clean, module-based, role-driven dashboard experience. Designed and implemented role-based dashboards with clear information hierarchy to improve operational monitoring, financial visibility, and decision-making for operations, finance, and management users. Introduced consistent theming and first-class geo-data visualization to better align the interface with real-world logistics workflows.
problem_statement: The existing logistics CRM interface had evolved organically with numerous side menus and fragmented internal modules, resulting in poor UX, high cognitive load, and limited visibility into operational and financial data. Users struggled to monitor workflows and derive insights efficiently from the system.
design_decisions: Collaborated closely with the UX design team to redefine information hierarchy and dashboard layouts
Translated UX concepts into scalable, reusable frontend components and layouts
Replaced menu-heavy navigation with module-based, role-specific dashboards
Designed role-based views to surface operational, financial, and performance metrics relevant to each user persona
Introduced consistent theming and layout standards to improve visual coherence across modules
Integrated geo-data and map-based visualizations as first-class UI elements for logistics monitoring
impact_metrics: Significantly improved usability and clarity for operations and finance teams
Enabled faster monitoring of logistics operations through dashboard-driven workflows
Reduced user confusion caused by fragmented legacy navigation structures
Established a scalable and maintainable frontend UI foundation for ongoing CRM evolution

title: LOGISTICS PLATFORM CONTRIBUTIONS — CRM & SELF-SERVICE PORTALS
description: Contributed to multiple frontend modules of a large-scale enterprise logistics platform during its early phase at Frugal Scientific, working across both the internal CRM system and a client-facing self-service portal. Implemented complex domain workflows on the frontend for customer, vendor, consignment, and contract management, along with vendor RFQ (Request for Proposal) creation and response flows. Focused on correctly modeling and rendering contract structures, multi-entity relationships, and state-driven workflows while maintaining consistency within a shared enterprise UI framework.
problem_statement: The logistics platform required continuous frontend development across multiple functional areas to support customer onboarding, vendor engagement, contract handling, and RFQ workflows while maintaining consistency within an evolving enterprise system.
design_decisions: Implemented frontend workflows for customer, vendor, consignment, and contract management within a shared enterprise platform
Handled complex contract and RFQ data models, including nested entities and state-dependent UI behavior
Contributed to vendor RFQ and response workflows supporting proposal creation, review, and status tracking
Worked on shared utilities and operational dashboards reused across multiple logistics modules
Ensured consistency with existing design systems, role-based access patterns, and shared components
Collaborated closely with senior engineers, product managers, and designers within a live production environment
impact_metrics: Supported core logistics workflows for customer, vendor, consignment, and contract management within the CRM
Enabled smoother vendor RFQ creation and proposal handling through structured frontend workflows
Contributed to shared dashboards and utilities used across logistics teams
Delivered production features safely within a complex, multi-module enterprise system
